references:
We compare the proposed method, FedRCL, with numerous client-side federated learning baselines [22, 29, 21, 19, 15, 18, 23, 33, 42] on the CIFAR and Tiny-ImageNet datasets.
Table 1 demonstrates that our framework outperforms all other existing algorithms by huge margins on all standard benchmarks with various settings.
Among the baselines, MOON shows meaningful performance improvement, but its gains are limited under severe data heterogeneity, e.g., α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05.
FedLC employs adaptive label margin to mitigate local deviations, but its effectiveness on performance is constrained.
FedDecorr exhibits marginal improvement and, in some settings, even degradation.
This suggests that unconditional alleviation of dimensional collapse does not necessarily benefit FL.
Compared to these works, our method achieves significant performance improvement across all datasets, regardless of the level of data heterogeneity.
We validate our framework in more challenging settings with lower client participation rates and the larger number of distributed clients.
Table 2 presents the robust performance improvement of FedRCL on three benchmarks, where we set a participation rate of 0.02 and vary the number of clients by {100,500}100500\{100,500\}.
All methods suffer from performance degradation compared to Table 1, due to the reduced client data, increased data disparity, and lower participation rate.
Particularly, FedProc suffers from a significant performance drop, because it relies on the global class prototypes aggregated from participating clients at each round, which may not accurately represent every class in this extremely low participation setting.
MOON exhibits performance degradation compared to FedAvg in some challenging configurations, partly because it utilizes outdated previous local models due to the sparse participation of local clients.
Despite these challenges, FedRCL consistently demonstrates outstanding performance across all datasets.

references:
We validate our framework in more challenging settings with lower client participation rates and the larger number of distributed clients.
Table 2 presents the robust performance improvement of FedRCL on three benchmarks, where we set a participation rate of 0.02 and vary the number of clients by {100,500}100500\{100,500\}.
All methods suffer from performance degradation compared to Table 1, due to the reduced client data, increased data disparity, and lower participation rate.
Particularly, FedProc suffers from a significant performance drop, because it relies on the global class prototypes aggregated from participating clients at each round, which may not accurately represent every class in this extremely low participation setting.
MOON exhibits performance degradation compared to FedAvg in some challenging configurations, partly because it utilizes outdated previous local models due to the sparse participation of local clients.
Despite these challenges, FedRCL consistently demonstrates outstanding performance across all datasets.

S5.T3.caption:
Table 3: 
Ablative results of contrastive training in the non-i.i.d. settings on the CIFAR-100 dataset.
S5.T3.table:
α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 α=0.3𝛼0.3\alpha=0.3
500R 1000R 500R 1000R 500R 1000R
Baseline 31.20 39.86 36.65 43.04 41.70 47.47
FedSCL 21.22 42.93 30.93 48.09 41.54 51.70
FedCL 35.29 41.45 40.39 45.91 45.99 50.16
FedRCL (ours) 43.71 54.63 49.82 58.23 57.89 63.46
references:
Table 3 compares the effectiveness of various contrastive learning strategies.
FedSCL is an ablative model of our framework, which incorporates a naïve supervised contrastive loss into the FedAvg baseline.
While FedSCL improves upon the baseline, its gains are moderate and even undergo degradation in the early stage of training.
In contrast, our full framework consistently enhances performance throughout the entire learning process, as also observed in Figure 1.
We also employ another variant, denoted as FedCL, which adopts a self-supervised contrastive loss [25], but its benefits are minimal.
This is partly because the objective of [25] does not directly align with mitigating the local deviations.

references: Table 4 presents the ablative results of our framework using only the last-layer feature outputs on the CIFAR-100 under various levels of data heterogeneity, which verifies that employing early-level representations contributes to achieve additional performance gain.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5: Integration of FedRCL into various server-side federated learning approaches under non-i.i.d. setting (α=0.3𝛼0.3\alpha=0.3).
S5.T5.table:
Method CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100 Tiny-ImageNet
FedAvgM [10] 85.48 53.29 38.51
FedAvgM + FedRCL 88.51 64.61 47.23
FedADAM [27] 81.82 52.81 39.74
FedADAM + FedRCL 85.69 57.84 41.57
FedAGM [14] 89.10 62.51 46.31
FedAGM + FedRCL 89.67 66.38 47.97
references:
Our framework is orthogonal to server-side algorithms, which enables seamless integration between FedRCL and other existing server-side approaches.
Table 5 presents the consistent and remarkable performance improvement when combining FedRCL with various server-side algorithms, such as FedAvgM [9], FedADAM [27], and FedAGM [14].

references:
We evaluate our method on different backbone architectures, including VGG-9 [34], MobileNet-V2 [31], ShuffleNet [43], and SqueezeNet [11] on the CIFAR-100 in Table 6, where we set β𝛽\beta to 2 for MobileNet and 1 for other cases.
Our framework consistently outperforms other existing approaches across various backbone networks by large margins, proving its robustness irrespective of the model architecture.
